question.title: How to set bootstrap classpath in NetBeans 24 on Windows 10
question.body:
I have set JAVA_HOME to C:\Program Files\Java\jdk-17 Path: includes %JAVA_HOME%\bin and I've reinstalled NetBeans 24 and ensured that the setup points to the jdk-17 file, and the Tools\Java Platforms only lists JDK-17, but I still get the following warning when I clean and build a project using the -Xlint:unchecked option (no errors are actually shown):

warning: [options] bootstrap class path not set in conjunction with -source 8 Note: Some input files use unchecked or unsafe operations.

No harm seems to be done, but I like to remove errors and warning if possible. Not sure what else I need to set. Thanks.

answers.body: I found that one of my library jar files had the project\Properties\Source set to JDK 8.

question_comments.body: When using an IDE, you need to understand how its build system works and how to control it. Don't let it control you. Netbeans traditionally used Ant and I suspect still does. Setting your target release to 24 will give you the latest features but will likely prevent your software being used elsewhere. The sensible choice is to compile to the lowest runtime version practicable for your codebase. My release version is often 9. 8 is really too low as it's really 'pre-watershed'. Were I to use Netbeans, I'd probably only use Maven projects and use Maven directly, though you could use GUI
Solved:  I found that one of my library jar files had the project\Properties\Source set to JDK 8.

I don't know how to change the project to run on JDK24.  The only JDK I have on my computer it JDK-17 and the only '8' I can find in my projects is UTF-8.  NetBeans 24 has been re-installed and the setup process allowed the choice of JDK-17 as the the default JDK.   Still puzzled, but greatly appreciate your help.
edit the question to correct the path.

You've configured your netbeans project to ensure your application would compile and run on a JDK8 (which is obsolete at this point). Hence that warning. The fix isn't to 'specify the bootstrap classpath' (you should not do that). The fix is to set the project to JDK24.
I do have %JAVA_HOME\bin, I misquoted in the question
Path: includes %JAVA_HOME% That's wrong, unless you mean %JAVA_HOME%\bin
